newsitem.title: INDIA: India's ruling coalition to meet on oil prices.
newsitem.headline: India's ruling coalition to meet on oil prices.

text.p: India's ruling United Front coalition was set to meet on Sunday to discuss the possibility of raising the domestic prices of some petroleum products, alliance officials said.

Representatives of the alliance's 15 parties were scheduled to begin the meeting at 3 p.m. (0930 GMT). Information Minister Jaipal Reddy was expected to address a news conference after 6:30 p.m. (1300 GMT).
Prime Minister Inder Kumar Gujral's centre-left coalition was expected to recommend raising the prices of some oil products to plug a ballooning subsidy bill.

Newspapers this week said the government had tentatively decided to raise the prices of diesel and kerosene with a plan that would trim about $1.5 billion from the subsidy bill but spare petrol users.

Under the plan, kerosene prices would be increased by 20 percent, while those of high speed diesel and liquified petroleum gas (LPG) would be raised by 15 percent. The price of petrol, which is not subsidised, would remain unchanged.
On Saturday, the Confederation of Indian Industry said the prices of high-speed diesel, LPG and kerosene should be increased immediately by 15 percent.
It also called for the phasing out of subsidies on those three petroleum products within two to three years.

But left-wing parties in the United Front were opposed to raising prices, and instead favoured increasing production, cutting import duties on crude oil and petroleum products and discouraging the use of luxury cars.
